title: Module 2: Foundations of EDA in Python for Analytics

sections.heading: What is EDA?
sections.content:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) is the process of examining, summarizing, and visualizing a dataset to understand its structure and key patterns before formal modeling. It helps answer questions like:
  • What does the data look like?
  • Are there missing values?
  • Are there outliers?
  • What trends or relationships can we spot?

sections.heading: Why Python is Great for EDA
sections.content:
Python is a top choice for data analysis because of its simplicity and powerful libraries. It allows analysts to work with data quickly and efficiently. Key libraries include:
  • pandas â€“ for loading and manipulating data
  • numpy â€“ for numerical operations
  • matplotlib â€“ for creating visualizations
  • seaborn â€“ for more advanced statistical plots

sections.heading: Loading and Exploring a Dataset
sections.content:
Start your analysis by loading the dataset and previewing its structure:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("sales.csv")
print(df.head())

This loads a dataset and shows the first 5 rows so you can get a quick glance at the data structure.

sections.heading: Basic EDA Calculations
sections.content:
Once your dataset is loaded, you can perform basic calculations to understand it:
print(df.describe())
print("Missing values:\n", df.isnull().sum())
print("Mean price:", df["price"].mean())
print("Median price:", df["price"].median())
print("Mode of category:", df["category"].mode()[0])
print("Standard deviation:", df["price"].std())
print("Min:", df["price"].min(), "Max:", df["price"].max())
print("Unique categories:", df["category"].nunique())

sections.heading: Visual EDA with Matplotlib
sections.content:
Charts and visualizations help reveal patterns and outliers that numbers alone may miss:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Line chart of monthly sales
df["sales"].plot(title="Monthly Sales")
plt.ylabel("Sales")
plt.show()

# Histogram of prices
df["price"].hist(bins=10)
plt.title("Price Distribution")
plt.xlabel("Price")
plt.show()

sections.heading: Common EDA Patterns to Watch For
sections.content:
• Outliers: Values that are unusually high or low
  • Missing Data: Gaps that need cleaning or imputing
  • Skewness: Distributions that are not balanced
  • Correlations: Variables that move together
  • Duplicates: Repeated rows that may affect analysis

sections.heading: Reflection
sections.content: Imagine you're working with a retail company's customer dataset. What are the first three things you'd check using EDA before building any dashboard or making recommendations? Write your thoughts and how Python can help you do it efficiently.
